Another reason to visit the Beverly Hills Public Library: As of this month, the Rexford Drive destination is the new home of the Paley Archive, which includes over 160,000 television and radio programs and advertisements, as preserved by The Paley Center for Media.
The archive spans more than a century of programming, across the genres of comedy, drama, news, public affairs, performing arts, sports, reality, animation, documentary and more. Monday nightâ€™s severe Coachella Valley windstorm, clocking in at 30 mph with gusts up to 50 mph, took down at least one Desert X sculpture installation, just over a week after the outdoor showâ€™s opening.
In Palm Desert, Swiss artist Raphael Hefti had stretched an impossibly long strip of reinforced fire-hose material, jet black on one side and mirror-bright silver on the other, between a high rocky cliff at one end and a tall steel support drilled into the flat desert at the other. Swaying overhead, the aerial strip was roughly 1,300 feet long â€” more than 3 Â½ football fields.
Monday nightâ€™s fierce winds took it down, damaging the support structures in the process. According to workmen at the site, repairs are expected to take a week to 10 days. Here are â€œbeforeâ€ (above) and â€œafterâ€ (below) photos of the work, titled â€œFive things you canâ€™t wear on TV,â€ a sly reference to cautions against wearing pinstripes on camera, lest moirÃ©â€¯patterns interfere with a television monitorâ€™s crisp electronic imagery.

After fire came perilously close to the Getty Villa during Januaryâ€™s devastating Palisades fire, Times art critic Christopher Knight asked a question: Should the Getty and Getty Villa move? Acknowledging that both structures are well protected by state-of-the-art building infrastructure, Knight pointed out that, â€œUrban fire â€” explosive structure-to-structure conflagrations, rather than ordinary ignition of wildland vegetation â€” had arrived at astounding scale.â€ But where would the collections go? Knight suggested the soon-to-be-vacant Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration in downtown L.A.
Needless to say, readers had many thoughts on Knightâ€™s column and suggestions, so we compiled their letters in a separate story. â€œAbsolutely not! The venue is a big part of both the Center and the Villa. That is what makes the Getty Museums so â€˜special.â€™â€ wrote one reader. â€œYes, definitely. The move to downtown Los Angeles would expose thousands more people to the incredible art of this priceless collection,â€ wrote another.
